title: How to Host an Educational Dinner

steps.headline: Select a date for your dinner.
Choose the venue and negotiate the best possible pricing.
steps.description: Whenever possible, you'll want to use a banquet room or private dining area for your event.

steps.headline: Rent a projector online.
steps.description: Renting from the restaurant may seem convenient, but you'll almost certainly overpay for your rental -- plus, there's no guarantee that anyone at the restaurant will be able to provide tech support if you have challenges with the equipment, as these options usually include antiquated units.

steps.headline: Create your guest list and invite participants.
steps.description: Insist on an RSVP because the restaurant will require you to provide a head count. Ask the restaurant whether you will be charged based on RSVPs or the actual number of diners.

steps.headline: People  sitting at an educational dinner are never going to give you their full  attention, so keep your presentation simple.
steps.description: The slides on the screen  should have as few words as possible and should be image heavy. Also,  don’t pack too many slides into the lecture. You will probably only have  the full attention of half the audience at any one time. The rest will  be paying attention to their food or possibly chatting with their  neighbors.

steps.headline: Arrive early to set up and prepare for your event.
Remember to thank your host and/or sponsor, as well as all the participants for their attention.
Avoid the temptation to cycle too quickly through  slides.
steps.description: You are probably going to have all of your data burned on to a  DVD that automatically progresses through the presentation. So, talk through  your speech beforehand. Time how long it takes you to cycle through  each section of the talk, and then add a few additional sections on to  that total. Then use this as the time between slides.

text: Select a date for your dinner.  Choose the venue and negotiate the best possible pricing. Whenever possible, you'll want to use a banquet room or private dining area for your event. Rent a projector online. Renting from the restaurant may seem convenient, but you'll almost certainly overpay for your rental -- plus, there's no guarantee that anyone at the restaurant will be able to provide tech support if you have challenges with the equipment, as these options usually include antiquated units. Create your guest list and invite participants. Insist on an RSVP because the restaurant will require you to provide a head count. Ask the restaurant whether you will be charged based on RSVPs or the actual number of diners. People  sitting at an educational dinner are never going to give you their full  attention, so keep your presentation simple. The slides on the screen  should have as few words as possible and should be image heavy. Also,  don’t pack too many slides into the lecture. You will probably only have  the full attention of half the audience at any one time. The rest will  be paying attention to their food or possibly chatting with their  neighbors. Arrive early to set up and prepare for your event.  Remember to thank your host and/or sponsor, as well as all the participants for their attention.  Avoid the temptation to cycle too quickly through  slides. You are probably going to have all of your data burned on to a  DVD that automatically progresses through the presentation. So, talk through  your speech beforehand. Time how long it takes you to cycle through  each section of the talk, and then add a few additional sections on to  that total. Then use this as the time between slides.
